author: sky.cactus
content: It is generally better to have separate solutions to separate problems rather than conflating them.  We pay for security with issuance, which is nice and clean.  When we are paying for security with a combination of issuance and transaction fees we end up with security payments being even more volatile than they already are.  This means we need to overpay for security even more because we have to compensate miners for the volatility risk they are taking.

author: sky.cactus
content: By using issuance only as the solution to paying for security, we remove some of the volatility risk that miners have to take on, which lets us pay toward a more specific target.

author: sky.cactus
content: I'll tell you the same harsh truth that I tell all miners.  Miners are service providers, they are paid to provide a very specific service which they provide very efficiently.  The service that they provide is security of the chain, and if we need less security then we should pay less for security, and if we need more security we should pay more for security.

author: sky.cactus
content: The goal of Ethereum isn't to enrich miners, it is to have a secure censorship resistant platform for global computing and that (at the moment) requires miners, so we pay them as much as we need in order to incentivize certain behaviors.

author: sky.cactus
content: There are certainly arguments to be made on both sides of the "how much security do we need" debate, and I have my own personal opinions on the matter (though they are muddied the more I understand the game theory of PoW security).  However, all of this I think should be kept separate from EIP-1559 discussion.  I don't think it would be at all unreasonable for someone to create an EIP that proposes an issuance increase that is launched around the same time as 1559 is launched, and that would be the appropriate place for discussion around that topic.

author: fktr2511
content:
> I am not sure you can actually overpay miners. If the profit margins increase that means that more hardware and locations become viable for mining, and theoretically that would result in higher hash rate and dropping profit margins. You can argue whether the certain hash rate is "too much", and this is probably the correct angle, not "miners are overpaid"
<@456226577798135808> thank you Alexey. Miners being overpaid is such a poor argument. Clearly from somebody who never mined, and assumes mining has been a really profitable job, which it hasn't bought my hardware in 2018, went through crypto winter not even being able to pay costs. Now that mining fee's are ok (depends, on your location, most of the world they aint ok). And obviously, I'm talking bout small ops (which are the ones community should take care of, the ones in which the small decentralisation left rests upon), not pools, or giant farms.
